name: Mark G. Schoesler
statement:
**Elected Experience**  
Elected to the Senate in 2004, 2008, and 2016 after serving 12 years in the State House. Elected State Senate Majority Leader for 2015 Legislative Session.

**Other Professional Experience**  
Self-employed farmer and rancher, raising cattle, wheat, hay, and canola. Member, Ways and Means; Member, Rules; Member, Labor and Commerce; Member, Select Committee on Pension Policy, Washington State Institute for Public Policy.

**Education**  
Graduate, Ritzville High School; Graduate, Spokane Community College (A.A.S., Agribusiness)

**Community Service**  
Former director, Washington Association of Wheat Growers; Member, Zion Philadelphia Church; Former vice president, Wheatland Communities Fair; Former president, Bronco Boosters; Past President of Washington Friends of Farms and Forests.

**Statement**  
As your senator, Mark Schoesler is dedicated to ensuring Eastern Washingtonâ€™s voice is heard in Olympia and has consistently advocated to limit tax increases, prioritize spending on infrastructure, and stand against Seattle policies and politicians.

As Washingtonians grapple with COVID-19, Sen. Schoesler supported emergency measures to keep people safe. Now, he is leading the charge on safely restarting our economy. Schoesler and Republican legislators crafted restart plans to get low-risk workers and small business owners back to their livelihoods.

As Senate Minority Leader, Sen. Schoesler pushed back against extreme Seattle sex-education policies that took local control away from schools. When he was Majority Leader, the percentage of the state budget going to education increased from 46% to 51%, college tuition was cut, and safety improvements have restarted on key highways. He remains focused on agriculture which reflects his background as a fifth-generation farmer in Ritzville. Mark has worked closely with counties, schools, hospitals, universities, and public safety officials to protect the services we depend on.

Sen. Schoesler is a proven compassionate, thoughtful, and effective leader in Olympia, and our district would be best served to retain him in his current leadership role.
